creator: gblock@ctoforaday.com
text:
Had a strange moment in a mounted DAV server running 2.1 release branch from CVS....

mv directory* directory/ where directory is, surprisingly enough, a directory.  It began, it seems, to 
create infinitely recursive directories under directory...

*not* sure if that's a bug in the move command, or an implementation problem with the client, but I'm 
going to guess it's a bug with the move dav method.

creator: luetzkendorf@apache.org
text:
What client you are using?
What does mean "it __seems__, to create infinitely recursive directories"?

Can you have a look at the webdav log (can be enabled in the web.xml)?
If there is really _one_ MOVE request for your mv command, it may be a server
problem.

Not sure what's happening here; J2EEStore may just be reporting something strange that then goes 
away on refresh, I think.  I just did it again with a move, and got a bit of insanity that went away with a 
refresh (DAV Explorer, this time, to get manual control over refresh).

http-8080-Processor4, 01-Nov-2004 17:12:17, gblock@ctoforaday.com, MOVE, 201 "Created", 48511 
ms, /files/wow/

Definitely single commands being sent; not sure what's causing it, and it is strange - but I'm not 
convinced it isn't just a factor of the current state of 2.1 CVS.  Today, I get the DAV Explorer saying that 
there's two "clients" directory under clients, and two "wow" directories; moments later, the refresh looks 
normal.

I say close me, treat it as stupid user error, and see if it happens on an RC, unless this rings a bell for 
anyone.
creator: gblock@ctoforaday.com
luetzkendorf@apache.org
text:
DAVexplorver shows sometimes some weird behavior, shows somtimes nothing
sometimes alle twice ...

And with WebFolders I observed recursively liked directories (each directoy
contains its self, beneth the other proper children)
In this case it seems to me that WebFolders implementation does not recognize
that http://any.host/webdav is tha same as http://any.host:80/webdav.

I'm quite sure its a client issue.

creator: gblock@ctoforaday.com
text:
Yes, I'd say that's likely the case - indeed, my host was :8080 on the system I was testing it on, and so 
yes, that probably is it.

It would be nice, however, if this got added to the usage notes for webfolders/mac desktop users.  Any 
chance of someone updating documentation to mention the problem with the use of non-:80 hosts?
